resources.string: Five Things to Save a Life
Five Things to Save a Life
FIRST - Place the victim on his or her back. Make sure he or she is lying as flat as possible.
SECOND - Push hard, push fast in the middle of the chest at least 2 inches (5 centimeters) deep and at least 100 compressions per minute.

THIRD - Tilt the head back and lift the chin up.
 - Pinch the nose shut then make a complete seal over the personâ€™s mouth.
 - Blow in for about 1 second to make the chest clearly rise.
 - Give rescue breaths, one after the other.

Note: If chest does not rise with rescue breaths, retilt the head and give another rescue breath.

FOURTH - Continue cycles of CPR. Do not stop CPR except in one of these situations:
 - You find an obvious sign of life, such as breathing.
 - An AED is ready to use.
 - Another trained responder or EMS personnel take over.
 - You are too exhausted to continue.
 - The scene becomes unsafe.
